H0.text: Transport of material inside the cell is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H1.text: The response of the cell to external pathogens is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H2.text: Storage of energy in stable long-term forms is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

H3.text: Direction of cellular activity is the cell function most directly dependent on the cytoskeleton.

A4.text: The cytoskeleton is involved in the uptake of extracellular material (endocytosis), the segregation of chromosomes during cellular division, and in intracellular transport (for example, the movement of vesicles and organelles within the cell).

A5.text: The anisotropy of the cytoskeleton serves to more keenly direct cell responses to intra or extracellular signals.

A6.text: Animation of leukocyte adhesion (Animation with some images of actin and microtubule assembly and dynamics.)

A7.text: Since intracellular transport heavily relies on microtubules for movement, the components of the cytoskeleton play a vital role in trafficking vesicles between organelles and the plasma membrane by providing mechanical support.

A8.text: Intracellular transport is required for maintaining homeostasis within the cell by responding to physiological signals.
